sanskrit_verse:
निग्रहेण हि पापानां साधूनां सङ्ग्रहेण च ।
द्विजातय इवैज्याभिः पूयन्ते सततं नृपाः ॥ ८.३११॥
transliteration: nigraheṇa hi pāpānāṁ sādhūnāṁ saṅgraheṇa ca | dvijātaya iva ejyābhiḥ pūyante satataṁ nṛpāḥ || 8.311||
sph_interpretive_translation: Rulers who restrain the wicked and protect the virtuous are ever honored, even as twice-born beings through sacrificial offerings.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority is derived from alignment with Dharma
Capacity-based responsibility demands discernment between virtue and vice
Restoration logic requires active support of righteousness
executable_legal_axioms: IF ruler does not restrain wrongdoers THEN withdrawal of honor and recognition
IF ruler protects virtuous THEN activation of public reverence protocols
IF societal harmony degrades THEN mandatory review of leadership capacity
IF dharmic order stabilizes THEN continuous affirmation of rightful authority
IF consciousness elevation declines THEN initiation of corrective governance measures
supreme_court_application: Supreme judicial authority must continuously assess whether executive actions align with the fundamental duty to uphold virtue and restrain vice. Failure in this regard constitutes a breach of constitutional dharma, necessitating realignment rather than punitive action.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Through pramāṇa-based observation, it is seen that rulers naturally receive honor when fulfilling their dharmic role. This causal sequence (anupūrvaśaḥ) reflects proportional responsibility: authority correlates directly with alignment to Dharma. There is no external punishment; consequence manifests organically through loss of legitimacy and social resonance.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate dharmic counseling for misaligned leaders
Reconnect ruler with foundational oaths and duties
Engage citizen assemblies to restore mutual trust
Activate spiritual guidance councils for course correction
Implement transparency mechanisms to reaffirm integrity
final_declaration: This law proceeds solely from the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam. Justice flows not through punishment but through restoration of Dharma. Reality itself enforces alignment; consciousness remains the ultimate adjudicator.
